description: Borrowed from (the participle stem of) Latin dērogāre (“to annul, repeal part of a law, take away, detract from”), from de- (“from”) + rogāre (“to propose a law, ask”). Compare abrogate, arrogate, interrogate.

adjectives.description: derogate (comparative more derogate, superlative most derogate)

verbs.description: derogate (third-person singular simple present derogates, present participle derogating, simple past and past participle derogated)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To partially repeal (a law etc.). [16th–17th c.]
examples: By several contrary customs,  […]  many of the civil and canon laws are controlled and derogated.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To detract from (something); to disparage, belittle. [from 16th c.]
examples: I never thought the human frailty of erring in cases of religion, infamy to a state, no more than to a council: it had therefore been neither civil nor christianly, to derogate the honour of the state for that cause [...].

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To take away (something from something else) in a way which leaves it lessened. [from 16th c.]
examples: Anything  […]  that should derogate, minish, or hurt his glory and his name.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To remove a part, to detract from (a quality of excellence, authority etc.). [from 16th c.]
examples: God does not have the attributes of a Christian Providence, for it would derogate from His perfection to think about anything except what is perfect, i.e. Himself.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To act in a manner below oneself; to debase oneself. [from 17th c.]
